Description: Terracotta mould-made protome of a woman. Fragment from right side of figure with hair. Traces of a orange-brown slip or paint. Local red-brown fabric with red core. Abundant fine gold mica, organics, clay pellets and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Protome bust (also known as a ‘shoulder-bust’) of early Classical Greek date (broadly 500BC to 400BC). The local Nile Delta fabric suggests this was produced in Naukratis, but in a Greek style. Parallels from Lindos, Rhodes, are dated between 525BC to 400BC (Blinkenberg 1931, 591, pl.120,Type B2) and in the British Museum from Rhodes, are dated to the 5th century BC (Higgins 1954, nos 237-9, 295). Similar pieces, not from the same mould, were found at Olynthus dated to the 5th century BC (Robinson 1952, pl.12, no.19; pl. 36, no.83; pl.38, nos 98 and 100). For context, function and details on protome parallels and fragments from Naukratis see protome records from Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology (NA350, NA355, NA354, NA353, NA390, NA850, NA426, NA803 and NA509). Blinkenberg, C. 1931. Lindos. Fouilles de l’Acropole 1902-1914, I. Les petits objets, Berlin. Robinson, D. M. 1952. Olynthus XIV. Terracottas, lamps, and coins found in 1934 and 1938. Johns Hopkins University studies in archaeology. Baltimore, Johns Hopkins Press; London, Oxford University Press.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.014) (Phase 1)
